title: Udeshi Salgado
text: I‚Äôm a PhD researcher at Cardiff University. My research focuses on hybrid intelligence and vaccine demand forecasting in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). I‚Äôm particularly interested in combining domain knowledge with probabilistic models to improve public health supply chains.

title: 9-Month Review
text:
The team

Student: Merennage Udeshi Prasangika Salgado
Supervisor 1: Prof.¬†Bahman Rostami-Tabar
Supervisor 2: Dr.¬†Thanos E Goltsos
Supervisor 3: Dr.¬†Xun Wang

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Thesis title
 
Enhancing Global Immunisation Supply Chain: Integrating Hybrid Intelligence Models¬†into Inventory Optimisation Considering Non-Monetary Welfare Metrics

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Research Problem
Our Focus
Addressing inefficiencies in infant routine vaccine supply chains, which includes:

inaccurate forecasting
standard wastage rates and buffer stock adjustments
frequent stockouts / missed vaccination opportunities
poor integration of inventory optimisation
the exclusion of societal well-being metrics like DALYs and QALYs.

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Research Problem
Why?

These inefficiencies result in stockouts, wastage, and missed vaccination opportunities, contributing to the preventable deaths

1 in 5 children worldwide lack access to lifesaving vaccines.
Globally, in 2023, 14.5 million children were zero-dose.
An additional 6.5 million children are partially vaccinated.
Annually, 1.5 million children under five die from vaccine-preventable diseases.

Solving this problem can save lives, reduce healthcare inequalities, and improve the efficiency of vaccine distribution.

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Research Problem
Who?

The research benefits public health systems, humanitarian organizations (e.g., UNICEF, GAVI), and vulnerable populations in developing countries
It also provides tools and insights for policymakers, researchers, and global health initiatives.

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Research Questions

How can a hybrid intelligence framework combining domain-specific knowledge and consumption-based probabilistic forecasting be leveraged to improve vaccine demand forecasting across the entire supply chain in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs)?
How can an objective/loss function incorporating both monetary and non-monetary welfare metrics (Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs), Quality-Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)) optimize vaccine inventory management to maximize fully immunized children in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs)?

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Research Questions Cont.


How can AI-driven predictive models accurately estimate open vial wastage at the health facility level in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs)?

title: 9-Month Review
text: Research Plan

title: 9-Month Review
text:
Modeling Framework for Work Package 1









Stage
Description




I. DATA PREPARATION
Clean the vaccine consumption dataset with hierarchical structure (region, county, sub-county). Standardize vaccine names and reporting periods. Derive `doses used` and `wastage` using two methods.


II. EXPLORATORY DATA ANALYSIS
Analyze seasonality, temporal continuity, and spatial variation in stock, doses administered, and wastage. Visualize patterns by vaccine type and region. Detect anomalies such as stockouts or overstocking.


III. FORECASTING COMPETITION
Compare two forecasting approaches:
- Approach A: Forecast `doses_used = stock_beginning + quantity_received - stock_end`, capturing total consumption.
- Approach B: Forecast `doses_administered` and `wastage` separately, then sum.
Run forecast competition including probabilistic and ML models with prediction intervals.

title: 9-Month Review
section: Modeling Framework for Work Package 1 Cont.
text:
Modeling Framework for Work Package 1 Cont.









Stage
Description




IV. ERROR METRICS AND EVALUATION
Evaluate models using point metrics (MAE, RMSE, MASE) and probabilistic metrics (Pinball loss, WIS, coverage).


V. HYBRIDIZATION WITH DOMAIN KNOWLEDGE
Incorporate Domain-Specific Features: Use attributes from current tools in practice as model features.
Human-in-the-Loop Adjustments: Allow expert overrides and feedback loops for continuous learning.


VI. FORECAST-TO-INVENTORY INTEGRATION
Translate forecasts into actionable inventory decisions using inventory policies ((s, S), min-max). Simulate effects of stockouts, overstocking, and missed vaccinations. Improve allocation strategies under uncertainty.
